skill.name: httpx
skill.description: A next-generation HTTP client for Python with both sync and async support, perfect for modern Python applications
skill.summary: Comprehensive Python HTTP client library documentation with sync/async APIs, HTTP/2 support, streaming, and authentication features
skill.author: community

security_audit.summary: This is documentation for HTTPX, a legitimate Python HTTP client library. All 62 static findings are false positives. The scanner misidentified markdown code fences (triple backticks) as Ruby/shell backticks, and example URLs (example.com) as hardcoded network endpoints. The file contains only documentation and code examples - no executable code, no external commands, no file operations, and no actual credential access.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution at SKILL.md:15
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Triple backticks in markdown are code fence delimiters, not Ruby/shell backticks for command execution. Line 15 begins a Python code block showing 'import httpx' - legitimate documentation example.

content.user_title: Use HTTPX for Python HTTP Requests
content.value_statement: Make HTTP requests in Python with both synchronous and asynchronous APIs. HTTPX supports HTTP/1.1 and HTTP/2, streaming, authentication, and timeouts for production applications.
actual_capabilities: Make synchronous and asynchronous HTTP requests with the same API
Configure authentication including Basic, Bearer token, and custom auth
Stream large files and responses without loading into memory
Handle timeouts, retries, and redirect following
Use connection pooling and HTTP/2 multiplexing
limitations: Does not include built-in retry logic (requires custom implementation)
WebSocket support requires separate httpx-ws package
SOCKS proxy support not included by default

use_cases.title: Build API clients
use_cases.description: Create REST API clients with authentication, timeouts, and error handling for Python applications.

use_cases.title: Download data streams
use_cases.description: Stream large datasets from APIs without memory issues using async or sync patterns.

use_cases.title: Integrate HTTP services
use_cases.description: Connect Python services to external APIs with proper authentication and connection management.

prompt_templates.title: Basic GET request
prompt_templates.prompt: Use httpx to make a GET request to https://api.example.com/data and print the JSON response with status code.

prompt_templates.title: Async batch requests
prompt_templates.prompt: Use httpx.AsyncClient to make 3 concurrent GET requests to user endpoints and return all results as a list.

prompt_templates.title: Authenticated requests
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an httpx client with Bearer token authentication and make a request to a protected endpoint.

prompt_templates.title: Stream download
prompt_templates.prompt: Use httpx streaming to download a large file to disk while showing progress with tqdm.

output_examples.input: Use httpx to fetch user data from https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/users/1

best_practices: Use AsyncClient for I/O-bound operations to improve throughput
Configure timeouts explicitly to prevent hanging requests
Reuse client instances for connection pooling and efficiency
anti_patterns: Creating a new client for each request instead of reusing
Ignoring timeouts and letting requests hang indefinitely
Loading entire responses into memory for large files

faq.question: What is HTTPX vs requests library?
faq.answer: HTTPX provides async support that requests lacks. Use HTTPX for async code and requests for simple sync scripts.

faq.question: Does HTTPX support HTTP/2?
faq.answer: Yes. Install with uv add httpx[http2] to enable HTTP/2 support in your project.

faq.question: How to handle timeouts in HTTPX?
faq.answer: Use httpx.Timeout(10.0, connect=5.0, read=8.0) to configure connect, read, and total timeout limits.

faq.question: Can HTTPX upload files?
faq.answer: Yes. Use client.post(url, content=file_stream) or multipart=files parameter for form uploads.

faq.question: How to use custom headers?
faq.answer: Pass headers={'Authorization': 'Bearer token'} to the Client constructor or individual requests.

faq.question: What async runtimes support HTTPX?
faq.answer: HTTPX supports anyio, asyncio, and trio. Configure with trust_env=False for custom event loops.
